title: Cutting — Cutting on Shapes (Circle and Square)
description: The child cuts along the outlines of a circle and square drawn on paper. This builds on straight-line and curve cutting, progressing to cutting out complete shapes.
instructions:
1. Draw or print a large circle (4-inch diameter) and a large square on separate papers.
2. Review proper scissor grip and the technique of turning the paper.
3. Demonstrate cutting along the circle outline: turn the paper smoothly while cutting.
4. Demonstrate cutting along the square: cut one side, rotate, cut the next side.
5. Let the child cut both shapes.
6. Glue the cut shapes onto a contrasting background paper.

slides.setup_instructions: Draw thick outlines of a circle (4 inches) and square (4 inches) on separate papers.

slides.text: 'Today we're going to cut out SHAPES! First, the circle. Remember: turn the paper, not the scissors.'
Demonstrate cutting the circle slowly, feeding the paper with the non-cutting hand.
'Now the square. Cut along one side, stop at the corner, turn the paper, cut the next side.'
Child cuts both shapes. 'It doesn't have to be perfect — you're learning!'

slides.prompt: Cut out your circle and square. Glue them onto the background paper to make a picture. What could they become?

slides.text: Display the shape art. 'You can cut circles AND squares now!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child cut out a recognizable circle and square shape?

parent_notes: Cutting out complete shapes is a significant milestone. Circles require continuous turning of the paper — a complex bilateral coordination task. Squares require stopping at corners and changing direction. Don't expect perfection; wobbly shapes are normal and will improve with practice. These cut shapes can be the start of shape collages, robots, animals, and other art projects.

title: Sandpaper Letters — o (short vowel) and Review
description: Introduction to sandpaper letter 'o' (short vowel as in 'octopus'). The child now knows three vowels and can build an even wider variety of CVC words.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'o' (blue background for vowel).
2. Trace while saying /o/ (short o, as in 'octopus'). Repeat 3 times.
3. Three-period lesson.
4. Review all 9 letters.
5. Build new words with /o/: top, mop, pot, cot, rot, cop.
6. Compare words: cat/cot, tip/top, pit/pot — changing the vowel changes the word!

slides.setup_instructions: Place 'o' on tray. Blue background — third vowel!

slides.text: 'Another vowel! This one says /o/ — like the beginning of octopus.' Trace the circular shape. Say /o/.
Child traces. Three-period lesson. Then review all 9 letters.
New words: /t/-/o/-/p/ = top! /m/-/o/-/p/ = mop! /p/-/o/-/t/ = pot!
Vowel swap: build 'cat' then change to 'cot.' Build 'tip' then change to 'top.' 'The vowel makes ALL the difference!'

slides.prompt: Build 5 words with /o/: top, mop, pot, cot, rot. Then try the vowel swap challenge with 3 word pairs!

slides.text: 'Three vowels now! a, i, o. Every word needs at least one vowel — they're the heart of every word.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify /o/ and build CVC words using all three vowels?

parent_notes: With three vowels (a, i, o) and six consonants (s, m, t, p, c, r), the child can now build dozens of real CVC words. The vowel swap exercise is powerful because it shows the child that vowels determine how a word sounds. Short /o/ is usually easy for children because it's a distinct, rounded sound. Keep building words daily — it's the most impactful language activity.

title: Cards and Counters — Practice and Odd/Even Games
description: Continued practice with cards and counters, deepening the understanding of odd and even numbers through games and daily life connections.
instructions:
1. Set up cards and counters independently.
2. Review: 'Which numbers are odd? Which are even?'
3. Odd/even game: call out a number, child says 'odd!' or 'even!'
4. Real-life connection: 'Can 3 people share 6 cookies equally?' (Even = yes!) 'Can 3 people share 7?' (Odd = one left over!)
5. Sort numeral cards into odd and even piles.
6. Extension: predict — is 12 odd or even? 15? 20?

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child set up cards and counters independently.

slides.text: 'Set up your cards and counters all by yourself today!' Observe and assist only if needed.
Point to numbers: 'Is 7 odd or even?' 'How can you tell?' (The bottom counter has no partner.)
Real-life: 'If we have 4 cookies and 2 people, can we share evenly? 4 is EVEN — yes! What about 5 cookies?'
Flash game: hold up a number, child says odd or even as fast as they can.

slides.prompt: Sort all the number cards into two piles: odd and even. Then predict: is 11 odd or even? Test it with counters!

slides.text: 'Odd, even, odd, even — it's a pattern that goes on forever!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child quickly identify numbers 1-10 as odd or even?

parent_notes: The connection to sharing ('Can we share fairly?') makes odd and even meaningful to children. Even numbers can be shared equally between two people; odd numbers always have one left over. Extending to numbers beyond 10 helps the child see the pattern: even numbers always end in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8. Don't teach this rule yet — let them discover it.

title: Continent Study — North America
description: Beginning an in-depth study of the continent where the child lives: North America. Learning about the countries, animals, and landmarks of the continent.
instructions:
1. Find North America on the globe (orange).
2. Show on a flat map: North America includes the United States, Canada, and Mexico.
3. Discuss: 'We live here! What do you know about where we live?'
4. Show pictures of North American animals: bald eagle, grizzly bear, moose, bison.
5. Show pictures of landmarks: Grand Canyon, Statue of Liberty, Niagara Falls.
6. Add a North America page to the Continent Book.
materials_needed: Pictures of North American animals and landmarks

slides.setup_instructions: Gather pictures beforehand. Have the globe and map available.

slides.text: Find North America on the globe. 'This is our home continent! It's the ORANGE one. It's the third largest continent.'
Show the map: 'Canada is to the north, the United States is in the middle, and Mexico is to the south.'
Show animal pictures: 'These animals live in North America. A bald eagle, a grizzly bear, a moose, a bison.'

slides.prompt: Add a North America page to your Continent Book. Color it orange. Draw one animal and one landmark. Write 'North America.'

slides.text: 'North America is a wonderful continent full of amazing animals and places!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate North America and name at least 2 countries within it?

parent_notes: Starting continent studies with the child's home continent makes the learning personal and meaningful. Use photos, books, or videos to bring the animals and landmarks to life. If you've visited any places in North America, share those stories. The continent study will continue over several weeks, one continent at a time, building a rich understanding of the world.

title: Read-Aloud: Corduroy
description: Reading Don Freeman's story about a stuffed bear who wants a home and a friend. Exploring themes of friendship, acceptance, and belonging.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is Corduroy. He's a teddy bear in a department store.'
2. Read the story with warmth and expression.
3. Pause at key moments: 'Why do you think the mother didn't buy Corduroy?'
4. Discuss: 'How did Corduroy feel when Lisa took him home?'
5. Talk about what makes a good friend.
6. Extension: bring a stuffed animal and tell its 'story.'
materials_needed: Optional: a stuffed bear for retelling

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably together.

slides.text: Cover: 'This is Corduroy. He lives in a big department store. He's waiting for someone to take him home.'
Read slowly. Let the child study the illustrations of the store at night.
Discuss: 'Corduroy went on an adventure at night! What was he looking for?' (His missing button.)

slides.prompt: After reading: 'Have you ever waited for something you really wanted? How did it feel? What makes Corduroy and Lisa good friends?'

slides.text: 'Lisa loved Corduroy just the way he was — even without his button. That's what real friends do.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the main events and discuss the friendship theme?

parent_notes: Corduroy teaches that love and friendship aren't about perfection — Lisa loved Corduroy even with a missing button. This is a wonderful book for discussing feelings: loneliness, hope, belonging, and joy. The nighttime department store adventure captivates children. If your child has a special stuffed animal, connect: 'Your bear is special just like Corduroy!'

title: Color Tablets — Box 2 Introduction
description: Introduction to Color Tablets Box 2, containing 11 pairs of colors (22 tablets). The child matches all pairs, discriminating between similar shades.
instructions:
1. Open Color Box 2. Spread all 22 tablets on the mat.
2. Pick up one tablet. 'I need to find the one that matches exactly.'
3. Compare by placing tablets side by side.
4. Find and pair all 11 colors: red, blue, yellow, orange, green, purple, pink, brown, gray, black, white.
5. Name each color using the three-period lesson as needed.
6. Arrange the matched pairs in a row.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the box on a neutral-colored mat. Handle tablets by the edges.

slides.text: 'Box 2 has MANY more colors! Let's spread them all out and find the matching pairs.'
Pick up a tablet. 'This looks orange. Let me find the other orange.' Compare side by side.
Some colors look similar (brown and orange, pink and red). 'Look carefully — are they the SAME or just similar?'
After matching all 11 pairs, name each color. Three-period lesson for any new color names.

slides.prompt: Mix all 22 tablets and match them again! This time, can you do it faster? Name each color as you match.

slides.text: 'Eleven colors! Your eyes can tell the difference between very similar colors now.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match all 11 pairs and name at least 8 colors?

parent_notes: Box 2 is a significant step up from Box 1 (which had only 3 pairs). The 11 pairs include some that are easy to confuse (brown/orange, pink/red, gray/white). Handle tablets by the wooden edges to keep the color surfaces clean. If your child doesn't have official color tablets, you can make pairs from paint chips at a hardware store.

title: Word Building — Three-Letter Phonetic Reading
description: The child begins reading CVC words independently. Moving from building words to READING pre-made words — a critical transition.
instructions:
1. Build a word with the moveable alphabet while the child watches: 'c-a-t.'
2. 'Can you read this word? Sound it out: /c/...../a/...../t/... cat!'
3. Build 5 more words. Child reads each one.
4. Now: write words on paper strips. Child reads the strips.
5. Match word strips to objects: 'cat' strip goes next to the cat toy.
6. This is the transition from writing to reading — celebrate!
materials_needed: Paper strips with CVC words written on them

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-write 8-10 CVC words on strips. Gather matching objects: cat, pot, mop, pin, etc.

slides.text: Build 'cat' with the moveable alphabet. 'Can you read this? Start at the beginning and say each sound.'
Child sounds out: '/c/...../a/...../t/... CAT!' 'You just READ a word!'
Build 5 more words. Let the child read each one independently. Help only if needed.
Switch to paper strips: 'Now read THIS word.' The child sounds out each written word.

slides.prompt: Match game: read each word strip and place it next to the matching object. Cat strip goes by the cat!

slides.text: 'You are READING! You can look at letters and figure out the word. That is reading!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sound out and read at least 5 CVC words independently?

parent_notes: This is a landmark lesson — the child transitions from encoding (building/writing words) to decoding (reading words someone else made). In Montessori, children typically write before they read. The matching activity proves comprehension: the child doesn't just say the word, they understand what it means. Keep the words phonetically regular — no silent letters or complex spellings yet.

title: Number Rod Combinations — Making 10 Review and Recording
description: Reviewing combinations that make 10 with number rods and recording them on paper as equations.
instructions:
1. Place rod 10 at the top of the mat.
2. Below it, place rod 9. 'What rod fills the gap to make 10?' Try rod 1. '9 and 1 make 10!'
3. Continue: 8+2, 7+3, 6+4, 5+5.
4. Record all combinations.
5. 'And 10 by itself makes 10!'
6. 'Making 10' is one of the most important number facts in all of mathematics.

slides.heading: Making 10!
slides.subheading: Number Rod Combinations — Making 10 Review and Recording

slides.setup_instructions: Have all rods ready. Place rod 10 at the top of the mat.

slides.text: Place rod 10 at the top. 'This is our target — TEN! Let's find all the ways to make ten.'
Place rod 9 below. 'What fills the gap?' Rod 1! '9 + 1 = 10!' Try 8 — need 2. '8 + 2 = 10!'
Continue: 7+3=10, 6+4=10, 5+5=10. 'Five and five make ten — that's a double!'
Record all combinations on paper. Read them aloud together.

slides.prompt: Find ALL the ways to make 10 with the rods. Can you do it without help? Write them down!

slides.text: 'Making 10 is one of the most important things in math! 9+1, 8+2, 7+3, 6+4, 5+5.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find at least 4 rod combinations that make 10?

parent_notes: Combinations of 10 are THE most important number facts in elementary math. They're used in mental math, regrouping, estimation, and more. Play '10 fingers': hold up some fingers, child tells how many are hidden to make 10. Make this a daily game: 'I have 3 apples, how many more to make 10?' Memorizing these combinations will serve your child for years.

title: Magnetic or Non-Magnetic — Introduction
description: The child experiments with a magnet to discover which objects are magnetic and which are not. Another classification exercise using the scientific method.
instructions:
1. Show the child a magnet. Let them feel it pull toward a metal object.
2. 'A magnet attracts some things but not others. Let's find out which!'
3. Gather 10-12 objects: paper clip, coin, wooden block, key, plastic cup, foil, nail, crayon, spoon, rubber band, rock, fabric.
4. Predict: 'Will the magnet attract this?' Test each one.
5. Sort into two groups: magnetic and non-magnetic.
6. Discuss: 'What do the magnetic objects have in common?' (They contain iron/metal.)
materials_needed: 10-12 test objects (mix of metal and non-metal)

slides.setup_instructions: Gather diverse objects. Include some tricky ones (aluminum foil is NOT magnetic even though it's metal!).

slides.text: 'This is a MAGNET. It has a special power — it can pull some things toward it. Watch!' Demonstrate with a paper clip.
'But it doesn't pull everything. Let's test!' Hold the magnet near a wooden block. 'Nothing happens — wood is not magnetic.'
For each object: predict, test, sort. 'Do you think this coin will be magnetic?'

slides.prompt: Test all the objects! Sort them into magnetic and non-magnetic groups. What do the magnetic ones have in common?

slides.text: 'Magnets attract objects that contain iron! That's why some metals are magnetic but plastic and wood are not.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child predict and test whether objects are magnetic and explain the pattern?

parent_notes: This experiment follows the same scientific method as sink/float: predict, test, observe. Children are fascinated by magnets. The key discovery is that not all metals are magnetic — aluminum, copper, and gold are not. Only iron-containing metals are. Let the child explore freely with the magnet after the structured lesson. Magnets are wonderful for independent investigation.

title: Clay Work — Pinch Pot
description: The child learns to make a simple pinch pot from clay. This develops hand strength, fine motor skills, and three-dimensional creativity.
instructions:
1. Provide a ball of clay (air-dry clay or modeling clay).
2. Demonstrate: roll into a smooth ball between palms.
3. Push thumb into the center of the ball to make a hollow.
4. Pinch and turn, pinch and turn — expanding the walls.
5. Even out the rim. Smooth the outside.
6. Let the pinch pot dry. Decorate later with paint.
materials_needed: Small bowl of water for smoothing

slides.setup_instructions: Knead the clay until pliable. Work on a mat or board to protect the table.

slides.text: 'Today we make something from clay! First, roll it into a smooth ball.' Demonstrate rolling between palms.
'Now push your thumb into the center — not all the way through! Make a little cave.'
'Pinch the walls between your thumb and fingers. Turn a little. Pinch again. Turn. Pinch. Turn.'
'Keep pinching and turning until the walls are even and the pot opens up. Smooth with wet fingers.'

slides.prompt: Make your own pinch pot! Can you make the walls even? Try making the rim smooth. What will you keep in your pot?

slides.text: Set the pot on a shelf to dry. 'You made a real pot from a ball of clay! People have made pots this way for thousands of years.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a basic pinch pot with recognizable walls and opening?

parent_notes: Pinch pots are one of humanity's oldest art forms. The repetitive pinch-and-turn motion builds hand strength and coordination. Air-dry clay is best for home use — no kiln needed. If the clay cracks, wet fingers smooth it out. Once dry, pinch pots can be painted with tempera or acrylic. This connects to cultural studies: many ancient civilizations made pinch pots.

title: Sewing — Introduction to Threading a Needle
description: The child learns to thread a large blunt needle with yarn. This is the foundation for all sewing work and develops fine motor control and patience.
instructions:
1. Present a large plastic or blunt metal needle and thick yarn.
2. Demonstrate: lick or tape the end of the yarn to stiffen it.
3. Hold the needle in one hand, the yarn in the other.
4. Poke the yarn through the eye of the needle.
5. Pull through and tie a knot at the end.
6. Let the child practice threading several times.

slides.setup_instructions: Cut yarn to about 18 inches. Wrap a small piece of tape around one end to stiffen it.

slides.text: 'Before we can sew, we need to learn to THREAD a needle. That means putting the yarn through the tiny hole.'
Show the eye of the needle. 'This hole is called the EYE. We push the yarn through it.'
Demonstrate: hold needle still, push stiffened yarn end through the eye. 'Got it! Now pull it through.'
Tie a knot at the other end. 'The knot keeps the yarn from pulling all the way through.'

slides.prompt: Practice threading the needle 5 times. Pull the yarn out and try again each time. It gets easier with practice!

slides.text: 'Threading a needle takes patience and steady hands. You did it!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child thread the needle independently at least once?

parent_notes: Threading a needle is genuinely difficult for young children and requires concentration, fine motor control, and patience. Use the largest needle and thickest yarn you can find for beginners. Taping or stiffening the yarn end is crucial — floppy yarn is nearly impossible to thread. This is a life skill as well as a Montessori exercise. Some children will find this frustrating; keep sessions short and praise effort.

title: Phonetic Reading — Object and Word Matching
description: The child reads CVC word cards and matches them to corresponding objects. Building reading comprehension through hands-on matching.
instructions:
1. Set out 8-10 small objects on a mat.
2. Place word cards face down in a pile.
3. Child turns over a card, sounds it out, reads the word.
4. Finds the matching object and places the card next to it.
5. Continue until all cards are matched.
6. Check together: 'Does pot match the pot? Yes!'
materials_needed: 8-10 small objects (cat, pot, cup, mat, pin, top, mop, rat, cap, rug)

slides.setup_instructions: Write one word per card in clear lowercase letters. Arrange objects on the mat with space between them.

slides.text: 'Here are some objects you know. And here are word cards. Can you read each card and find the matching object?'
Turn over the first card. 'Sound it out: /m/...../o/...../p/... MOP! Where is the mop?'
Place the card next to the object. Continue with each card.

slides.prompt: Match all the word cards to their objects. Read each word aloud as you place it. Can you get them all right?

slides.text: 'You READ every word and matched it! That proves you understood what you read. You are a reader!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and correctly match at least 6 out of 8 word cards?

parent_notes: Object-to-word matching proves that the child is not just decoding (making sounds) but comprehending (understanding meaning). This is a crucial distinction. If the child can sound out 'mop' but doesn't connect it to the mop object, they need more work on blending sounds into words. Keep all words phonetically regular at this stage — no sight words or tricky spellings yet.

title: Numeral Writing on Paper — 1 through 5
description: Transitioning from sand tray to paper. The child writes numerals 1-5 on lined paper for the first time, using proper formation learned through sandpaper numerals.
instructions:
1. Review sandpaper numerals 1-5: trace each one.
2. Write each numeral in the sand tray first.
3. Present lined paper and pencil.
4. Demonstrate writing 1: straight line down.
5. Child writes a row of 1s. Then 2s. Continue through 5.
6. Circle their best one on each row.

slides.setup_instructions: Have sandpaper numerals and sand tray for warm-up. Then switch to paper and pencil.

slides.text: Warm up: trace each sandpaper numeral. Then write each in the sand tray.
'Now let's try on PAPER! Paper is special because your writing stays.' Show how to hold the pencil.
Demonstrate writing 1: start at the top line, straight line down to the bottom line. 'Now you try.'
Continue with 2, 3, 4, 5. Each number gets one row. 'Take your time. Big, clear numbers.'

slides.prompt: Write a row of each numeral: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. Circle your BEST one in each row!

slides.text: 'You're writing real numbers on real paper! Soon we'll do 6 through 10.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write recognizable numerals 1-5 on lined paper?

parent_notes: The progression is sandpaper tracing → sand tray writing → paper writing. Each step reduces support. Don't expect perfect formation on paper yet — the muscles are still developing. Wide-ruled paper is important; regular-lined paper is too small. Let the child self-assess by circling their best attempt — this builds metacognition (thinking about their own work).

title: Grace and Courtesy — Saying Please and Thank You
description: Practicing polite words in context through role-play. The child learns when and how to say please, thank you, and you're welcome naturally.
instructions:
1. Discuss: 'What are magic words that make people feel good?'
2. Role-play asking for something: 'May I please have the scissors?'
3. Role-play receiving something: 'Thank you!' Response: 'You're welcome!'
4. Practice different scenarios: at the table, at a store, with a friend.
5. Role-play: what happens WITHOUT magic words? 'Give me that!' How does it feel?
6. Make a 'Please and Thank You' pledge together.
materials_needed: Optional: small items to pass back and forth for practice

items: Small items to pass back and forth
slides.setup_instructions: Gather a few objects to practice giving and receiving.

slides.text: 'There are special words that make everyone feel happy and respected. They're called POLITE words.'
Model: 'May I PLEASE have the crayon?' Take it. 'THANK YOU!' Response: 'You're WELCOME!'
Practice: pass items back and forth using please and thank you every time.
Contrast: 'Give me that!' How does that feel? 'May I please have that?' How does THAT feel?

slides.prompt: Role-play: ordering food at a restaurant, borrowing a toy from a friend, receiving a gift. Use please and thank you each time!

slides.text: 'Please and thank you cost nothing but they make everyone feel valued.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use please, thank you, and you're welcome in appropriate contexts?

parent_notes: Grace and courtesy lessons work best when they're reinforced all day long, not just during the lesson. Model these words yourself — children learn more from what they see than what they're told. Don't force a child to say thank you in the moment (that can create anxiety); instead, model it and practice through play. Over time, it becomes natural.

title: Nursery Rhymes — One Two Buckle My Shoe & Jack Be Nimble
description: Learning two counting/action nursery rhymes. These combine numerical sequence with rhyme and movement.
instructions:
1. Teach 'One Two Buckle My Shoe' slowly, with actions for each pair.
2. 'One, two — buckle my shoe!' (pretend to buckle) 'Three, four — shut the door!' (push shut)
3. Continue through 'nine, ten — a big fat hen!'
4. Teach 'Jack Be Nimble' — set up a small 'candlestick' (rolled paper) to jump over.
5. Recite and jump! Vary: jump high, jump low, jump slowly, jump quickly.
6. Review all 10 nursery rhymes learned so far.
materials_needed: Small object to jump over (rolled paper 'candlestick')

slides.heading: Nursery Rhymes
slides.subheading: One Two Buckle My Shoe & Jack Be Nimble

slides.setup_instructions: Clear space for jumping. Make a 'candlestick' from a rolled piece of paper.

slides.text: Teach 'One Two Buckle My Shoe' with actions: buckle shoe, shut door, pick up sticks, lay them straight, big fat hen!
Repeat together. Count along — this rhyme practices counting to 10!
'Jack be nimble, Jack be quick, Jack jump over the candlestick!' Jump over the paper tube!

slides.prompt: Jump over the candlestick in different ways: two feet, one foot, backward! Then try to recite ALL 10 nursery rhymes.

slides.text: 'Ten nursery rhymes in your collection! You're a rhyme expert!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recite both new rhymes and count along?

parent_notes: 'One Two Buckle My Shoe' naturally practices counting by twos and connects numbers to rhyming words — a bridge between math and language. 'Jack Be Nimble' is perfect for burning energy while learning. Adding physical challenges (jump backward, jump on one foot) develops gross motor skills alongside language. These movement rhymes are great for transitions or energy breaks during the school day.

title: Brown Stair — Extensions and Language
description: Brown Stair extension work with vocabulary: thick, thin, thicker, thinner, thickest, thinnest. The child arranges the prisms and uses comparison language.
instructions:
1. Build the Brown Stair.
2. Introduce vocabulary: pick up the thickest prism. 'This is THICK.' Pick up the thinnest. 'This is THIN.'
3. Compare two prisms: 'This one is THICKER. This one is THINNER.'
4. Superlatives: 'This is the THICKEST of all. This is the THINNEST of all.'
5. Three-period lesson for thick/thin vocabulary.
6. Extension: build the stair with eyes closed, using only touch!

slides.setup_instructions: Build the stair on the mat first. Then use it for language and extensions.

slides.text: Build the stair. Hold up the thickest prism: 'This is THICK.' Hold the thinnest: 'This is THIN.'
Compare two: 'This one is THICKER than this one. This one is THINNER.'
Three-period lesson: 'Show me thick. Show me thin. Which one is thicker?' 'What is this — thick or thin?'
Eyes-closed extension: mix up 3 prisms. Can you order them thick to thin just by feeling?

slides.prompt: Build the Brown Stair, then try the blindfold challenge with 3 prisms! Can you feel which is thicker?

slides.text: 'Thick, thicker, thickest. Thin, thinner, thinnest. Your hands and eyes both know the difference!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use thick/thin vocabulary correctly and order by touch?

parent_notes: Adding precise vocabulary to sensorial materials is a key Montessori practice. The child first experiences the concept (through the material), then receives the language (vocabulary). This order — experience before language — means the words have deep meaning. The blindfold extension isolates the tactile sense, making discrimination even more precise.

title: Metal Insets — Quatrefoil and Combining Shapes
description: Metal inset work with the quatrefoil shape and creating designs by combining multiple inset shapes on one paper.
instructions:
1. Present the quatrefoil metal inset (four overlapping circles).
2. Trace and fill as usual.
3. Then: take two different insets (e.g., circle and triangle) and overlap them on the same paper.
4. Trace both. The overlapping area creates a new shape!
5. Fill different sections with different colors.
6. This creates beautiful geometric art.
materials_needed: Metal insets (quatrefoil plus 2 others of child's choice)

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child choose which shapes to combine.

slides.text: 'The quatrefoil is a special shape — it has four round petals!' Trace and fill.
'Now let's try something new: put two shapes on the SAME paper!' Place a circle inset, trace. Place a triangle overlapping, trace.
'See the area where they overlap? That's a NEW shape! Color each section a different color.'

slides.prompt: Create 2 overlapping designs using different shape combinations. Use many colors. Which is your favorite?

slides.text: Display your designs. 'When shapes overlap, they create new patterns. That's geometry art!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a multi-shape overlapping design with different colors?

parent_notes: Overlapping shapes is a significant extension of metal inset work. It introduces the geometric concept of intersection (where shapes overlap, a new shape is created) in a beautiful, hands-on way. This work is also excellent for decision-making: which shapes? which colors? where to overlap? The results look like stained glass windows and make wonderful gifts.

title: Numeral Writing on Paper — 6 through 10
description: Continuing numeral writing on paper with numerals 6-10. The child completes the full set of single-digit numeral formation.
instructions:
1. Review sandpaper numerals 6-10: trace each one.
2. Write each in the sand tray.
3. Transition to paper: demonstrate 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.
4. Special attention: 10 is TWO digits! '1 and 0 together make ten.'
5. Child writes a row of each: 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.
6. Review: write all numerals 0-10 in order.

slides.setup_instructions: Warm up with sandpaper and sand. Then transition to paper.

slides.text: Warm up: trace sandpaper numerals 6-10. Write each in the sand tray.
Paper: demonstrate 6 (curve down and around). '6 curls like a snail!'
Continue: 7 (across and down), 8 (S curve then close), 9 (like 6 upside down), 10 (a 1 and a 0 together).
'10 is special — it's our first two-digit number! It takes TWO numerals to write ten.'

slides.prompt: Write a row of each: 6, 7, 8, 9, 10. Then write all numbers from 0 to 10 in order!

slides.text: 'You can write every number from zero to ten! That's eleven different numbers!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write recognizable numerals 0-10?

parent_notes: Numerals 6 and 8 are the trickiest to form. 6 is often written backward (looking like a lowercase 'g') and 8 requires a smooth S-curve. Don't worry about perfect formation — it improves with practice over weeks and months. Note that 10 introduces the concept of a two-digit number. This is a BIG idea: we need two symbols because we ran out of single digits after 9.

title: Magnetic or Non-Magnetic — Extension and Magnet Strength
description: Extending the magnet experiment by testing whether magnets work through different materials and exploring magnet strength.
instructions:
1. Review: 'What did we learn about magnets last time?'
2. New question: 'Can a magnet work THROUGH things?'
3. Test: put a paper clip on a piece of paper. Move the magnet under the paper.
4. Try through cardboard, fabric, plastic container, water, thin wood.
5. Test magnet strength: how many paper clips can the magnet hold in a chain?
6. Record results on a simple chart.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather various materials for the magnet to work through.

slides.text: 'Last time we learned WHAT magnets attract. Today we ask: can magnets work THROUGH things?'
Place a paper clip on paper. Move the magnet underneath. 'It moved! The magnet works through paper!'
Test through cardboard, fabric, a plastic container (put clip inside), thin wood. Record: yes or no.
Strength test: how many paper clips can chain from the magnet? Count your chain!

slides.prompt: Test all the materials. Record your results. Then build the longest paper clip chain you can!

slides.text: 'Magnets work through thin materials! The magnet's force can pass through paper, fabric, and even water!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child test and record whether the magnet works through each material?

parent_notes: This extension deepens the child's understanding of magnetic force. The key discovery is that magnetism passes through non-magnetic materials (paper, fabric, plastic, water) but is blocked by thick or magnetic materials. The paper clip chain measures 'magnet strength' in a child-friendly way. This is real physics! Let the child play freely with magnets after the lesson.

title: Music — Fast and Slow (Tempo)
description: Exploring tempo in music: fast and slow. The child listens to, moves to, and creates music at different speeds.
instructions:
1. Clap a steady beat. 'This is a medium speed.' Clap faster. 'FAST!' Clap slower. 'Slow...'
2. Play or sing a familiar song at regular speed. Then faster. Then slower.
3. Let the child move: walk fast, walk slow. March to the tempo.
4. Use an instrument (drum or shaker): child plays fast when you say fast, slow when you say slow.
5. 'Tempo' means how fast or slow music goes.
6. Listen to two different songs — which is faster?
materials_needed: Music player with two contrasting songs (one fast, one slow)

slides.setup_instructions: Choose a fast song and a slow song to compare. Clear space for movement.

slides.text: 'Music can go FAST — ' (clap quickly) ' — or SLOW — ' (clap slowly). 'This is called TEMPO.'
Sing 'Twinkle Twinkle' at regular speed. Then super fast! Then very slow. 'Which sounds best?'
'Let's move to the tempo! When I play fast, move fast. When I play slow, move slow.'

slides.prompt: Play the drum at different tempos. Can you switch from fast to slow and back? Move your body to match!

slides.text: 'We've learned loud/soft, high/low, and now fast/slow. These are the building blocks of music!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and produce fast versus slow tempos?

parent_notes: We've now covered three fundamental music concepts: dynamics (loud/soft), pitch (high/low), and tempo (fast/slow). Movement is the best way for young children to internalize tempo — they feel the speed in their bodies. Classical music offers wonderful examples: compare a waltz (slow, graceful) with a march (fast, energetic). Dancing to music is learning!

title: Sewing — Running Stitch on Burlap
description: First sewing project: the running stitch on burlap or loose-weave fabric. The child sews in and out along a drawn line.
instructions:
1. Thread the needle (review from day 3).
2. Draw a straight line on burlap with a marker.
3. Demonstrate: push needle up through the fabric, pull through, push down through the fabric.
4. 'Up, down, up, down — like a dolphin swimming!'
5. Follow the line. Stitches should be roughly even.
6. Tie off at the end. Admire the work!
materials_needed: Burlap or loose-weave fabric (6x6 inch piece)

slides.setup_instructions: Thread the needle. Draw a straight line across the burlap. Optional: secure burlap in hoop.

slides.text: Thread the needle together (review). Draw a straight line on the burlap.
'We're going to sew along this line. Watch: push the needle UP from underneath.' Pull through.
'Now push it DOWN a little bit ahead.' Pull through underneath. 'UP again!' Continue along the line.
'Up, down, up, down — like a dolphin jumping in and out of the water!'

slides.prompt: Sew along the entire line with the running stitch. Try to keep your stitches roughly the same size.

slides.text: 'You SEWED! That line of stitches is called a running stitch. People have been sewing for thousands of years.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete a line of running stitches along the drawn path?

parent_notes: Burlap is ideal for first sewing because the loose weave makes it easy to push the needle through. An embroidery hoop holds the fabric taut, making sewing easier. Don't worry about stitch size consistency — that comes with practice. Sewing develops patience, fine motor skills, hand-eye coordination, and a sense of accomplishment. Many children become absorbed in sewing work.

title: Oral Language — Retelling a Story
description: The child practices retelling a familiar story in their own words. Building narrative skills, sequencing, and oral fluency.
instructions:
1. Choose a story the child knows well (from recent read-alouds).
2. 'Can you tell me the story of Corduroy? What happened first?'
3. Help with sequence prompts: 'And then what happened? What came next?'
4. Encourage details: 'What did the store look like? How did Corduroy feel?'
5. If the child gets stuck, offer a choice: 'Did he go upstairs or outside?'
6. Celebrate the retelling! 'You told that whole story yourself!'
materials_needed: A familiar picture book for reference

slides.setup_instructions: Choose a book the child has heard at least twice. Have it nearby but closed.

slides.text: 'You know the story of Corduroy so well. Can you TELL it to me? Pretend I've never heard it!'
Prompt: 'How does the story start? Where is Corduroy?' Let the child narrate.
Guide with questions: 'What happened next? Then what? And at the end?'
Encourage details: 'What did Corduroy look like? How did Lisa feel?'

slides.prompt: Retell the whole story from beginning to end. Use the pictures in the book if you need help remembering.

slides.text: 'You told that whole story! You remembered the beginning, middle, and end. You're a storyteller!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell a familiar story with a clear beginning, middle, and end?

parent_notes: Story retelling is one of the strongest predictors of reading comprehension. The child must remember events, sequence them logically, and express them in their own words — complex cognitive work! Don't interrupt to correct; let the child's version flow. You can gently add details after: 'You told it so well! I also remember that...' Make retelling a regular activity after every read-aloud.

title: Memory Game — Quantities with Challenge Numbers
description: The Memory Game with higher numbers and multiple rounds. Building mental number sense and working memory for larger quantities.
instructions:
1. Set up the Memory Game as in week 5.
2. This time, include numeral cards for 7, 8, 9, and 10 more frequently.
3. Play 5 rounds with challenging numbers.
4. Extension: draw TWO cards and add them. 'You drew 3 and 4. How many total? Bring back 7!'
5. Another extension: 'Bring me 6 red beads and 4 blue beads.'
6. Verify each time by counting together.
materials_needed: Numeral cards 1-10 (with extras of high numbers)

slides.setup_instructions: Place objects across the room. Include extra cards for 7, 8, 9, 10.

slides.text: 'The Memory Game is back — with a CHALLENGE! This time, the numbers might be bigger.'
Draw a card: '9! That's a big number. Remember it. Walk over. Count out 9. Bring them back!'
Extension: draw two cards. '3 and 5. How many is that together? Walk over and bring back 8!'
Color challenge: 'Bring me 4 red and 3 blue.' Child must remember BOTH the quantity AND the color.

slides.prompt: Play 5 challenge rounds. Try the two-card addition version! Can you add and remember?

slides.text: 'Your number memory is getting stronger! You can hold big numbers in your head!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child accurately gather quantities up to 10 and attempt simple addition from memory?

parent_notes: The two-card extension turns the Memory Game into an addition game — the child must add mentally AND hold the sum in working memory while walking and counting. This is challenging! If the child struggles with the addition extension, stick with single cards until they're ready. The two-color version adds another layer of complexity that develops working memory.

title: Celebrations Around the World — Diwali
description: Learning about Diwali, the Festival of Lights celebrated primarily in India. Exploring how different cultures celebrate with light, food, and togetherness.
instructions:
1. Find India on the globe (Asia, yellow continent).
2. 'In India and many other countries, people celebrate DIWALI — the Festival of Lights!'
3. Show pictures of Diwali: oil lamps (diyas), rangoli patterns, fireworks, special foods.
4. Explain: 'Diwali celebrates the victory of light over darkness and good over bad.'
5. Make a simple rangoli pattern with colored rice or chalk.
6. Light a small candle together (supervised) to celebrate light.
materials_needed: Small candle and matches (for adult use)

slides.setup_instructions: Print or display Diwali images. Prepare colored rice in small bowls.

slides.text: Find India on the globe. 'India is in ASIA — the yellow continent. It's one of the biggest countries in the world!'
'People in India celebrate DIWALI — the Festival of Lights! They light thousands of small lamps called diyas.'
Show pictures: diyas, rangoli patterns on floors, fireworks, sweets. 'Diwali celebrates light winning over darkness.'

slides.prompt: Make a rangoli! Draw a simple symmetrical pattern on paper or the ground. Fill it with colored rice or chalk. Light a candle to celebrate light!

slides.text: 'Diwali reminds us that light and goodness always win. People all around the world celebrate in special ways.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what Diwali celebrates and locate India on the globe?

parent_notes: Learning about celebrations from around the world builds respect for cultural diversity. Diwali is one of the world's most widely celebrated festivals. Keep the explanation age-appropriate: light over darkness, good over bad. Making rangoli (colorful floor patterns) is a wonderful hands-on cultural activity. If you have neighbors who celebrate Diwali, this is a beautiful opportunity for connection.

title: Read-Aloud: Strega Nona
description: Reading Tomie dePaola's Italian folktale about Big Anthony and a magic pasta pot. Exploring themes of responsibility, consequences, and different cultures.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'Strega Nona means Grandma Witch in Italian. She has a magic pasta pot!'
2. Read with expression. Use a special voice for Strega Nona.
3. Build suspense when Big Anthony uses the pot alone.
4. 'Uh oh! The pasta won't stop! What should he do?'
5. After reading: 'What lesson did Big Anthony learn?'
6. Discuss: 'Have you ever done something you were told not to? What happened?'

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably together.

slides.text: Cover: 'This story comes from ITALY. Strega Nona has a MAGIC pasta pot. But what happens when someone else uses it?'
Read with character voices. Build suspense as pasta overflows!
After: 'Why couldn't Big Anthony stop the pot? What did Strega Nona know that he didn't?'

slides.prompt: 'What lesson did Big Anthony learn? Have you ever been told not to do something but did it anyway? What happened?'

slides.text: 'When we don't listen to instructions, things can go wrong — even with magic! That's a lesson from Italy.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the cause and effect in the story?

parent_notes: This Caldecott Honor book teaches about consequences in a humorous, non-threatening way. Children love the escalating disaster of overflowing pasta. The Italian setting connects to geography (find Italy on the globe!). Big Anthony's punishment (eating all the pasta) feels fair to children's sense of justice. Folktales from different cultures are a cornerstone of Montessori cultural studies.
